description: An entity that is visually present in the storytelling, a core to the story, and a device to contextualize what is transpiring for the audience. A story should only have one main character.
While the main character has to be constantly visible, they may not have to be a consistent entity.
A visual element (character) that will navigate the audience through the story plot to the conclusion.
ICC can range from an abstract representation (e.g., colors) to an actual human. We have identified 7 types.
An antagnonist introduces the conflict to the main character.
An antagnonist can take two forms: character or force. While the former is visually present, the latter exists but is not directly visible.
An antagnonist force can be either misconception or misunderstanding. Misconception is mistaken belief, whereas misunderstanding suggests the difference in the interpretations of a concept.
Conflict is what leads the audience to understand the motivation of the story.

Conflict assumes two forms, internal and external conflict. Internal when a character struggles with their opposing desires or beliefs; external when a character is against something beyond their control.
Whether the conflict is addressed visually, e.g., the story provides context when the conflict is associated with lack of context.
The other characters whose desires align with that of either the main character or the antagonist character.
A support character can be alternative representation of the MC/AC (e.g., supporting views) or provide extra information to the desire of the MC/AC (e.g., labels, annotations, axes).
The primary concept that all the sub-concepts relate to
The distinguishable aspects that are relevant to the primary concept. They become desires for data characters.
The primary intent of an author when composing a story.
The distinguishable aspects that are relevant to the primary concept. They become desires for data characters.
note: Reveal Anomalies, Issues, or Unintended Consequences

citation.content: Initially identified as 7 types by INSERT, later re-organized as 5 types by us.

description: Classification and organization of works into categories.
